TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {1647=As of Seguin Housing Authority’s most recent Resident Characteristics Report (June 30, 2015), the 16-month average number of units occupied was 188 out of a total 188 rental units. This represents a 16-month average vacany rate of 0%., 994=Residents of public housing pay rent based on their income. The rent contribution of the tenant is called the Total Tenant Payment (TTP). The TTP is generally 30% of a residents income with a $25 (National minimum) to $50 (some PHA’s) minimum rent. Based on the information in the most recent Resident Characteristics Report (June 30, 2015) the minimum rent in Seguin Housing Authority's public housing developments is $50.}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {3558=As of the last HUD RCR report (June 30, 2015), there were a total of 188 households containing 480 total persons residing in the housing authority’s public housing properties. The average household size across all properties in the housing authority’s public housing portfolio was 2.6., 9069=From 2001 to 2009, Seguin Housing Authority scored an average of 97 points as of the last set of publicly available data. The housing authority had a high score of 100 in 2002 and a low score of 84 in 2001. The average SEMAP Score for Housing Authorities in Texas is 74.11.}
textBeforeTable: Following are the HUD-approved public housing agency plans for Seguin Housing Authority. The housing authority plans include specific details about the cost of renovations to real estate (also known as capital improvements), changes to Section 8 HCV policies, planned redevelopment of public housing projects and other major administrative changes. Public housing agencies, also called public housing authorities, which receive funding from HUD, are required to submit and receive approval from the US Department of Housing and Urban Development of both an Annual Plan and a 5 Year Plan. These plans establish each housing authority’s policies, strategies, programs and operations for meeting the housing needs of persons within their target area. Housing Authority Annual and 5 Year Plans The REAC score of a property is a good reflection of the overall quality of the property and the experience residents will have. Prospective renters should use the REAC score as an overall reading of how the property is maintained and the quality of management. Properties with lower scores should be avoided. Score are often followed by a letter or asterisk. A score followed by the letter “a” signifies that no health and safety concerns were noted. A score followed by the letter “b” denote non life threatening health and safety issues were discovered in the inspection.
